bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to James F. Waters, November 22, 1941

div1.p: Hench gives Waters information on Kissinger, a copy of his yellow fever article, and a list of names and addresses of other yellow fever volunteers. He requests the address of Forbes' mother and a script of the "Court of Missing Heirs" program concerning Forbes.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to James F. Waters, November 22, 1941

opener.dateline:
November 22, 1941 Mr. James F. Waters
The Court of Missing Heirs
Radio Program
572 Madison Avenue
New York City

div1.p:
Since receiving your nice note of October 2 in answer to my letter
of September 29 with reference to your broadcast of September 23 regarding
Wallace W. Forbes I have been away and regret indeed this delay in answering
you. You asked me if I knew that one of Dr. Reed's volunteers appeared in
“We the People.” Yes, it was Mr. John R. Kissinger of Route S, Huntington,
Indiana. I have the radio script but the date is not given thereon. Mr. Lord
gave the opening remarks. It was prior to April, 1937. I think Kissinger has
talked on the radio a couple of times since then in connection with openings of
the movie “Yellow Jack”. I have had correspondence and visits with him since
1937. He recently had a stroke but is recovering. His stroke came just two
or three days after a ceremony at which he, Walter Reed's daughter and I par-
ticipated. Regarding that ceremony I enclose a recently published article--the
address I gave. It will place Kissinger correctly in the yellow fever story.

Mr. John J. Moran, Sunoco Oil Co., Avenida Menocal 455, Havana, Cuba,
was with Kissinger one of the first two to volunteer to Reed. I have visited
him in Havana twice. It is my recollection that about a year ago he was brought
to New York to speak on some radio program but I am almost positive it was not
“We the People”.

For your help I am sending you the names and addresses of the survivors
of the actual yellow fever experiments. You may wish to send them one of the
mimeographed Reviews of your Sept. 23 broadcast or if you will send me sufficient
copies, ten or fifteen more (you only sent me five or six) I will send them out
as I correspond with them frequently. I append their addresses. I am not hopeful
that they will know Forbes' whereabouts since the government knows their addresses
and doubtless would have written them about Forbes long ago. But I am keeping
after the yellow fever story, finding new data and new contacts here and there,
and will certainly keep my ears open regarding Forbes.

Would you do two things for me, please. Send me (1) Mrs. Forbes'
Chicago address. I'd like to send her one of my reprints similar to the enclosed.
(2) Send me a copy of the script (not just the note) you used regarding Forbes on
September 23. I should appreciate having these.
If I can help in any way further please let me know.
div1.closer:
Sincerely, P. S. Hench, M. D. Names and addresses
John H. Andrus, 805 Cooper Street, Camden, N. J.
John R. Bullard, Box 59, St. Augustine, Florida (later experiments).
Dr. Robert P. Cooke, Lexington-Rockbridge Health Dept., Lexington, Va.
Capt. Thomas M. England, 1715 East Long St., Columbus, Ohio.
James L. Hanberry (address in 1937) 61 Summers Ave., Orangeburg, S. C.
Clyde L. West, Riverdale, Md.
The names of these men and their relation to Reed are given in my
reprint. Also more or less directly connected therewith were:
General Albert E. Truby, 145 Laurel St., San Francisco, California.
Dr. Alva Pinto, 1229 First National Bank Bldg., Omaha, Nebraska.
Mr. John R. Taylor, 548 Grand Ave., Upper Darby, Pa.
